basics.name: Benjamin (Ben) Glasner, Ph.D.
basics.label: Senior Economist
basics.summary: Senior Economist at the Economic Innovation Group (EIG). Researcher and writer focused on labor markets, place-based policy, and how social-policy design shapes economic opportunity and well-being.

work.name: Economic Innovation Group
work.summary: Conducts applied economic research and public-facing analysis on U.S. labor markets, wages, and place-based policy.
highlights: Author and coauthor of major reports and working papers on wage subsidies, transfer income dependence, Opportunity Zones, housing supply, and labor-market measurement
Develops original empirical analyses using CPS, ACS, SIPP, HUD–USPS vacancy data, and administrative sources
Produces public-facing writing, figures, and data visualizations for policymakers, media, and general audiences

work.name: Center on Poverty and Social Policy, Columbia University
work.summary: Conducted empirical research on major U.S. social policies and reforms, including the expanded Child Tax Credit, poverty dynamics, and intergenerational mobility.
highlights: Peer-reviewed and policy-facing research on employment, mental health, and material hardship
Collaborated with CPSP faculty including Irwin Garfinkel, Jane Waldfogel, and Christopher Wimer

work.name: University of Washington
work.summary: Led survey and qualitative analysis for equity- and inclusion-focused institutional research initiatives.
highlights: Designed and analyzed surveys and focus groups involving faculty, staff, students, alumni, and donors
Synthesized qualitative and quantitative feedback for senior leadership

work.name: University of Washington
work.summary: Primary instructor for undergraduate coursework in public policy and economics.
highlights: Curriculum delivery and assessment across students with diverse backgrounds

work.name: World Bank Group (via University of Washington)
work.summary: Conducted expenditure and survey-data analysis addressing missingness and seasonality in household data.
highlights: Contributed to a World Bank working paper
Applied survey-data methods in development contexts
